    • Method Detail

      • dijkstra

        public static <N,V> List<N> dijkstra(DirectedValuedGraph<N,V> graph,
                                     N src,
                                     N dst,
                                     Function<V,Double> costFunction)
        Finds a shortest path in the graph from the source node to the destination node using Dijkstra's algorithm with the provided cost function.

        Returns the shortest path as a sequence of nodes where the first node is the source and the last node is the destination. If there is no path in the graph from the source to the destination, then this method will return the empty path. If the source is the destination, then this method will return a singleton path.

        The cost function extracts the "cost" of an edge (for the purposes of finding a "shortest" path) from the "value" of an edge as it is represented in the given DirectedValuedGraph. The cost function should never return a negative cost. Given a null (i.e. non-existent) edge value, the cost function should return positive infinity.

        Parameters:
        graph - The graph in which to find a shortest path
        src - The source node from which a shortest path is to be found
        dst - The destination node to which a shortest path is to be found
        costFunction - A function that extracts the numeric representation of the "cost" of an edge given the value associated with an edge
        Returns:
        A shortest path in graph from src to dst as induced by costFunction
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If costFunction ever returns a negative cost in the course of executing Dijkstra's algorithm over the given problem instance
        NoSuchElementException - If either of src or dst is not contained in graph
        NullPointerException - If any argument is null
        See Also:
        DirectedValuedGraph, Function, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY
        API Note:
        The cost function is primarily beneficial in situations where the "value" of an edge is a complex non-numeric type with multiple attributes, and only one of its attributes should be used to find a shortest path.
        Implementation Requirements:
        Input validation should be performed in order of nullity check, then existential check.

        You may create additional helper methods and nested classes with private static access within this class -- in fact, you are encouraged to do so. You may also add additional public methods to DirectedValuedGraph and MappedMinPriorityQueue -- however, this is discouraged (but will not hurt your grade).
